title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0001
text: Which package contains the Deque interface?
explanation: The Deque interface is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0002
text: Which of the following interfaces does Deque extend?
explanation: The Deque interface extends the Queue interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0003
text: What does 'Deque' stand for?
explanation: Deque stands for Double Ended Queue, allowing insertion and removal at both ends.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0004
text: Which of the following classes implement the Deque interface?
explanation: ArrayDeque and LinkedList are common implementations of the Deque interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0005
text: Which of the following is true about Deque?

options.text: Deque allows insertion and removal at both ends
Deque allows insertion only at the head
Deque allows removal only at the tail
Deque allows insertion only at one end

explanation: Deque supports insertion and removal of elements at both ends.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0006
text: Which of the following methods adds an element at the front of a Deque?
explanation: The addFirst(E e) method inserts an element at the front of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0007
text: Which of the following methods adds an element at the end of a Deque?
explanation: The addLast(E e) method inserts an element at the end of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0008
text: Which of the following methods removes the first element of a Deque?
explanation: The removeFirst() method removes and returns the first element of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0009
text: Which of the following methods removes the last element of a Deque?
explanation: The removeLast() method removes and returns the last element of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods retrieves but does not remove the first element?
explanation: The peekFirst() method retrieves but does not remove the first element of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0011
text: Which of the following methods retrieves but does not remove the last element?
explanation: The peekLast() method retrieves but does not remove the last element of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0012
text: Which of the following methods throws an exception if the deque is empty when removing the first element?
explanation: The removeFirst() method throws NoSuchElementException if the deque is empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0013
text: Which of the following methods throws an exception if the deque is empty when removing the last element?
explanation: The removeLast() method throws NoSuchElementException if the deque is empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0014
text: Which of the following methods adds an element at the front without throwing an exception if full?
explanation: The offerFirst(E e) method adds an element at the front and returns false if the deque is full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0015
text: Which of the following methods adds an element at the end without throwing an exception if full?
explanation: The offerLast(E e) method adds an element at the end and returns false if the deque is full.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and null elements?

options.text: Most Deque implementations do not allow null elements
All Deque implementations allow null elements

explanation: Most Deque implementations, such as ArrayDeque, do not allow null elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and duplicates?

options.text: Deque throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: Deque allows duplicate elements unless restricted by a specific implementation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and ArrayDeque?

options.text: ArrayDeque is faster than Stack for stack operations

explanation: ArrayDeque is faster than Stack for stack operations and does not allow null elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and LinkedList?

options.text: LinkedList implements both List and Deque

explanation: LinkedList implements both List and Deque interfaces.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and stack operations?

options.text: Deque can be used as a stack using push() and pop()
Deque cannot be used as a stack

explanation: Deque can be used as a stack using push() and pop() methods.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0021
text: Which of the following methods removes and returns the element at the front of the deque?
explanation: The pollFirst() method removes and returns the first element of the deque, or null if empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0022
text: Which of the following methods removes and returns the element at the end of the deque?
explanation: The pollLast() method removes and returns the last element of the deque, or null if empty.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0023
text: Which of the following methods pushes an element onto the stack represented by the deque?
explanation: The push(E e) method inserts an element at the front of the deque, acting as a stack push operation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0024
text: Which of the following methods pops an element from the stack represented by the deque?
explanation: The pop() method removes and returns the first element of the deque, acting as a stack pop operation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and LIFO behavior?

options.text: Deque can act as a LIFO stack
Deque cannot act as a LIFO stack

explanation: Deque can act as a LIFO stack using push() and pop() methods.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and FIFO behavior?

options.text: Deque can act as a FIFO queue
Deque cannot act as a FIFO queue

explanation: Deque can act as a FIFO queue using offerLast() and pollFirst() methods.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and null elements in ArrayDeque?

options.text: ArrayDeque does not allow null elements

explanation: ArrayDeque does not allow null elements because null is used as a special return value.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and thread safety?

options.text: Deque is not thread-safe by default

explanation: Deque is not thread-safe by default; concurrent implementations like ConcurrentLinkedDeque are thread-safe.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0029
text: Which of the following is a thread-safe implementation of Deque?
explanation: ConcurrentLinkedDeque is a thread-safe implementation of the Deque interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and BlockingDeque?

options.text: BlockingDeque extends Deque and supports blocking operations
BlockingDeque is a subtype of Set

explanation: BlockingDeque extends Deque and supports operations that wait for space or elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and LinkedBlockingDeque?

options.text: LinkedBlockingDeque is a thread-safe implementation of BlockingDeque

explanation: LinkedBlockingDeque is a thread-safe implementation of the BlockingDeque interface.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and fail-fast behavior?

options.text: Iterators of most Deque implementations are fail-fast

explanation: Iterators of most Deque implementations are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and duplicates?

options.text: Deque throws an exception for duplicates

explanation: Deque allows duplicate elements unless restricted by a specific implementation.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and capacity?
explanation: Some Deque implementations like LinkedBlockingDeque are bounded, while others like ArrayDeque are unbounded.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and peekFirst() vs getFirst()?

options.text: peekFirst() returns null if empty, getFirst() throws exception
peekFirst() throws exception if empty, getFirst() returns null

explanation: peekFirst() returns null if the deque is empty, while getFirst() throws NoSuchElementException.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and peekLast() vs getLast()?

options.text: peekLast() returns null if empty, getLast() throws exception
peekLast() throws exception if empty, getLast() returns null

explanation: peekLast() returns null if the deque is empty, while getLast() throws NoSuchElementException.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and push() vs addFirst()?
explanation: The push() method is equivalent to addFirst(), inserting an element at the front.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and pop() vs removeFirst()?
explanation: The pop() method is equivalent to removeFirst(), removing the element at the front.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and iteration order?

options.text: Deque iterates from first to last element
Deque iterates from last to first element

explanation: Deque iterates from the first to the last element by default.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and descendingIterator()?

options.text: descendingIterator() iterates from last to first element
descendingIterator() iterates from first to last element

explanation: The descendingIterator() method iterates from the last to the first element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and clear()?

options.text: clear() removes all elements from the deque

explanation: The clear() method removes all elements from the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and size()?

options.text: size() returns the number of elements in the deque
size() returns the capacity of the deque

explanation: The size() method returns the number of elements in the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and isEmpty()?

options.text: isEmpty() returns true if the deque has no elements
isEmpty() returns false if the deque has no elements
isEmpty() throws an exception if empty
isEmpty() returns the size of the deque

explanation: The isEmpty() method returns true if the deque contains no elements.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and contains()?

options.text: contains() checks if a specific element exists

explanation: The contains() method checks if a specific element exists in the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and removeFirstOccurrence()?

options.text: removeFirstOccurrence() removes the first occurrence of a specified element

explanation: The removeFirstOccurrence() method removes the first occurrence of a specified element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and removeLastOccurrence()?

options.text: removeLastOccurrence() removes the last occurrence of a specified element

explanation: The removeLastOccurrence() method removes the last occurrence of a specified element.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and descendingIterator() order?

options.text: descendingIterator() iterates from tail to head
descendingIterator() iterates from head to tail

explanation: The descendingIterator() method iterates from the tail to the head of the deque.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and fail-fast iterators?
explanation: Fail-fast iterators throw ConcurrentModificationException if the deque is modified during iteration.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about Deque and BlockingDeque methods?

options.text: putFirst() and takeLast() block until space or elements are available
putFirst() and takeLast() throw exceptions if full or empty
putFirst() and takeLast() remove all elements
putFirst() and takeLast() clear the deque

explanation: The putFirst() and takeLast() methods in BlockingDeque block until space or elements are available.

title: JavaCollectionsFrameworkDeque - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes the Deque interface?

options.text: A double-ended queue supporting insertion and removal at both ends
A queue that supports only FIFO operations
A collection that stores unique elements only

explanation: The Deque interface represents a double-ended queue supporting insertion and removal at both ends.
